column3: lit. cold river in the Ket language) is a town and the administrative center of Tayshetsky District in Irkutsk Oblast
column5: located 669 kilometers (416 mi) northwest of Irkutsk
column6: the administrative center of the oblast. Population: 35

column1: It was founded in 1897 as a supply point and station on the Trans-Siberian Railway and was granted town status in 1938.

column2: Tayshet was the center of administration for gulag labor camps Ozerlag and Angarstroy. Construction of the first section of the Baikal–Amur Mainline started in 1937 and was managed from here. According to some survivor accounts
column3: between Tayshet and Bratsk there is "a dead man under every sleeper."  Along with Japanese prisoners from the Kwantung Army
column4: German prisoners of war formed a large proportion of the forced labor contingent
column6: such as Dietrich von Saucken. Surviving German POWs were repatriated in autumn of 1955
column7: after West German Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's visit to Moscow.

column1: Within the framework of administrative divisions
column2: Tayshet serves as the administrative center of Tayshetsky District
column3: to which it is directly subordinated. As a municipal division
column4: the town of Tayshet is incorporated within Tayshetsky Municipal District as Tayshetskoye Urban Settlement.

column1: Tayshet has a subarctic climate (Köppen Dfc) bordering on a humid continental climate with warm
column3: drier winters. The monthly 24-hour average temperature ranges from −18.9 °C (−2.0 °F) in January to 18.4 °C (65.1 °F). Sunshine is generous and the area receives 2

column1: Tayshet railway station is a major railway junction. Here the Baikal–Amur Mainline begins
column2: branching northeast from the Trans-Siberian Railway. Here also the Abakan-Taishet Railway ends.  The town is also on the M53 Highway (Moscow to Irkutsk).
